results.headline: Review: Carrying On and Making Movies in ‘Their Finest’
results.summary_short: Gemma Arterton stars in this World War II drama about a screenwriter who’s hired to create uplift and propaganda. From the director of “An Education.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Their Finest

results.headline: Review: Gertrude of Arabia in ‘Queen of the Desert’
results.summary_short: Nicole Kidman plays Gertrude Bell, the British adventurer, archaeologist and linguist who has been labeled the female Lawrence of Arabia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Queen of the Desert

results.headline: Review: ‘Colossal,’ With Anne Hathaway, Jason Sudeikis and Giant Monsters
results.summary_short: In Nacho Vigalondo’s film, two childhood friends drink, talk about life and bring their inner resentments to a scary boil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Colossal

results.headline: Review: A ‘Gifted’ Girl at the Center of a Custody Battle
results.summary_short: A young math prodigy and her strong bond with her uncle are tested when a debate arises over whether to cultivate her abilities or let her be a child.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gifted

results.headline: Review: Out of the Dark, Temptation Abounds in ‘The Ticket’
results.summary_short: In this drama, Dan Stevens is exceptional as a blind man who is less than happy with what he sees after his sight is restored.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ticket

results.headline: Review: ‘Truman’ Focuses on a Man Whose Days Are Numbered
results.summary_short: This low-key drama, in which a dying actor tries to find a home for his dog, may largely sidestep easy sentiment, but it is not as sensitive as it first appears.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Truman

results.display_title: SHOT! The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock
results.headline: Review: ‘SHOT!,’ About the Man Who Captured Rock’s Famous Faces
results.summary_short: Mick Rock, the British photographer with the cool name and starry portfolio (Blondie, Lou Reed, David Bowie) is the subject of a new documentary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of SHOT! The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock

results.headline: Review: Seeking Revenge for ‘The Assignment’ She Didn’t Want
results.summary_short: In Walter Hill’s film, a revenge plot is set in motion after a hit man, played by Michelle Rodriguez, undergoes a forced gender reassignment surgery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Assignment

results.headline: Review: Openly Inviting Ridicule in ‘i hate myself :)’
results.summary_short: A filmmaker turns the camera on her yearlong relationship with a would-be performance artist. Neither one seems to be good dating material.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of i hate myself :)

results.headline: Review: ‘Five Came Back,’ and Inspired the Likes of Spielberg
results.summary_short: A screen adaptation of Mark Harris’s 2014 book adds visuals to the story of five Hollywood directors who served in World War II with cameras in tow.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Five Came Back

results.headline: Review: ‘The Blackcoat’s Daughter’ Is Bewitching and Bloody
results.summary_short: Three narratives converge in a gorgeously filmed, deeply unsettling horror film about girls stranded at their boarding school during midterm break.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Blackcoat's Daughter

results.headline: Review: ‘The Death of Louis XIV’ Has a Riveting Performance at Its Heart
results.summary_short: Albert Serra’s new film is a showcase for a beloved star of French cinema, Jean-Pierre Léaud.

results.headline: Review: A Descent Into Mental Illness in ‘God Knows Where I Am’
results.summary_short: A documentary recalls the life of Linda Bishop, who had a psychotic disorder and fell through the cracks of New Hampshire’s medical establishment.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Ghost in the Shell,’ a Cyborg With Soul
results.summary_short: Scarlett Johansson, playing a cyborg called Major, rises above it all in the thrill-free science fiction thriller.

results.headline: Review: ‘All This Panic,’ a Cinematic Confidant of Teenage Girls
results.summary_short: This limber, light-footed documentary becomes a sort of dreamy film diary for the girls it profiles.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Boss Baby’ Puts Alec Baldwin in Diapers, Sort Of
results.summary_short: An animated feature starring a newborn with an oh-so-familiar voice may confuse the kiddies, but grown-ups should get a kick out of it.

results.headline: Review: ‘Carrie Pilby,’ Saved by Bel Powley, Superhero
results.summary_short: A 19-year-old British prodigy fresh out of Harvard pursues some semblance of a normal life in New York.

results.headline: Review: Before ‘Eraserhead’ There Was ‘David Lynch: The Art Life’
results.summary_short: A documentary profile of this filmmaker focuses not on his big-screen features, but on his early development as a painter.

results.headline: Review: ‘Here Alone’ Will Scare You With Menacing Little Jolts
results.summary_short: A woman struggles to survive the aftermath of a deadly virus in a movie that is more psychodrama than postapocalyptic adventure.

results.display_title: Tony Conrad: Completely in the Present
results.headline: Review: Tony Conrad, ‘Completely in the Present’
results.summary_short: This documentary captures the antic personality of Mr. Conrad, an avant-garde musician and experimental filmmaker who died last year.
